title: Consumer Credit
description: A consumer credit contract is an agreement to borrow money for personal use. The lender lends you money and in exchange you pay the lender fees plus interest (unless the loan is interest free). In some situations, such as a mortgage or hire purchase, the lender will have the right to sell one or more of your assets if you can’t repay the loan.

modules.title: What is a consumer credit contract?

content.content_html: A consumer credit contract is an agreement to borrow money for personal use. The lender lends you money and in exchange you pay the lender fees plus interest (unless the loan is interest free). In some situations, such as a mortgage or hire purchase, the lender will have the right to sell one or more of your assets if you can’t repay the loan.
content.title: What is a consumer credit contract?
Advance
content.content_html: Advance is an amount of money that a lender pays to a borrower. Sometimes there can be multiple advances for the same loan. For example, a lender could pay an initial advance when a borrower takes out the loan and another advance 1 year later.

content.title: Borrower
content.content_html: Borrower is a person who has borrowed money from a creditor.

content.title: Creditor
content.content_html: Creditor is a person or business who lends money to a borrower, such as a bank or financier.

content.title: Debt
content.content_html: Debt is an amount of money that a borrower still owes to a creditor.

content.title: Disclosure
content.content_html: Disclosure is information that is shared with someone, such as when a lender shares information with a borrower before the contract is signed.

content.title: Default
content.content_html: Default is when someone breaks the credit contract, such as failing to keep up with repayments.

content.title: Interest
content.content_html: Interest is the amount that a lender charges for providing money to a borrower. It’s the cost that a borrower must pay to use money, for example to buy a house.

content.title: Repossession
content.content_html: Repossession is when a lender takes secured items and sells them to recover money owing under a credit contract.

content.title: Security
content.content_html: Security means any asset listed in a credit contract that a lender can repossess and sell if a borrower defaults on their loan.

content.title: Unforeseen
content.content_html: Unforeseen hardship is an unexpected event that means a borrower cannot reasonably continue regular repayments.

Lenders are permitted to charge reasonable fees to cover any costs connected to lending you money. Lenders are not permitted to make a profit by charging fees. You must be told about the fees before you sign the credit contract. Common fees include set-up (establishment) fees, default fees, early repayment fees, overdraft fees and dishonour fees.
content.title: Sumary

modules.title: Have you been charged an unfair fee?

content.content_html:
Fees charged must be reasonable

The Supreme Court found that to be reasonable, fees must be sufficiently close and relevant to the establishment of the loan, the administration and maintenance of the loan, or to the actual consequences of the default. General overheads are not recoverable through fees. Sportzone Motorcycles Limited (In Liquidation) v Commerce Commission [2016] NZSC 53 at [113].
content.title: Fees charged must be reasonable

modules.title: If your lender fails to provide you with complete and accurate information, you may be entitled to a refund

content.content_html: If a disclosure statement does not give full and accurate information, then your lender may be required to refund some, or all the fees or interest charged to you during the time that the disclosure statement was incorrect. Your lender may also need to pay compensation to you. You can also cancel your credit contract in these circumstances.
content.title: If a disclosure statement does not give full and accurate information...

content.content_html: While a disclosure statement is incorrect or incomplete, your lender must not enforce any rules in your contract (including rights to repossess goods).
content.title: Incorrect/Incomplete

modules.title: Check that your lender has shared all required information

content.content_html: Before agreeing to a loan, you should check that your lender has shared all required information to you. By law, lenders must make give you a disclosure statement before you sign anything. This statement sets out key information, including money lent, obligations, security, and your right to cancel.

modules.title: Do you have a right to cancel your contract?

content.content_html:
The disclosure statement must say that borrowers have 5, 7 or 9 days to cancel the contract depending on whether the documents were received in person, electronically, or by post, respectively
Seed Credit Limited incorrectly disclosed to borrowers that they had 3, 5 and 7 days to cancel depending on the method of disclosure (in person, electronically, or by post, respectively). The Commerce Commission warned that this error made Seed Credit’s disclosure statement was non-compliant.
content.title: Borrowers must have 5,7 or 9 days to cancel the contract
